content:
Hey! I think we should write up a help center page about the in-app ? help menu. We could then link to this page as a reference from https://zulip.com/help/keyboard-shortcuts and https://zulip.com/help/search-for-messages, so that users know how to look things up without having to go to the help center.

What should we call this menu? https://zulip.com/help/keyboard-shortcuts uses two names for it in different places:

  • Keyboard shortcuts view
  • Shortcuts help

The in-app tooltips vary based on the tab that opens:

  • "Message formatting" for the ? in the compose box that opens the "Message formatting" tab.
  • "Keyboard shortcuts" for the keyboard button in the bottom right that opens the "Keyboard shortcuts" tab.

CC @David Rosa to expect an issue coming your way. :)
For a help center article, we probably need a general name that covers all three tabs (the two above + "Search operators").
I'll kick off a poll with some initial ideas; please add more!

/poll What should the ? menu be called?
Shortcuts help
Shortcuts reference
Shortcuts cheatsheet
Reference card

Briefly, I think this is tricky since it is 'in app help', but it covers such a wide range that a broad name appears inadequate.

The option I added is not specifically what I would go with, but something along the lines of X, Y & Z Reference.

In some ways I like that the popup is combined as a broad help reference, but equally it seems strange to have the keyboard icon (bottom right) access all 3 parts, and similarly the ? icon when composing a message. I'm unsure if there's something similar for searching.

Was it an explicit choice to place these together?
Could possibly be just a technical decision since they share the same underlying code.

Surely products like Google and Dropbox Paper that have similarly extensive lists of keyboard shortcuts have had to figure out what to call this sort of thing; maybe we should see if they have a name for them?
I don't like the names like "Shortcuts" because the search help and message formatting references are definitely not things people will think of as "shortcuts".

Tim Abbott said:

Surely products like Google and Dropbox Paper that have similarly extensive lists of keyboard shortcuts have had to figure out what to call this sort of thing; maybe we should see if they have a name for them?

I don't think other products particularly combine keyboard shortcuts, formatting info, and search filters into a single menu, which is what creates the naming challenge here.
To be fully correct, we either need to list all of these out separately, or use a generic term like "Reference card", "In app help", "Reference info menu", etc.

"Cheat sheet" is probably too informal, but something like "Reference card" could be fine. FWIW it's called "information overlays" in the code, which isn't helpful at all.

But I think probably the current approach of not having a user-facing name for the "Keyboard shortcuts reference" / "Search filters reference" / etc. is probably better than making up a new name that isn't super intuitive. It's a nice touch that you can switch between them easily, but from a user standpoint, that's probably not super salient to you -- at any given time you probably just want the specific one you're looking for.
OK, so the proposal is to just have canonical names for the three panels, and document how to get those panels in the relevant help pages? That could work.
In that case, should it be "{Keyboard shortcuts/Message formatting/Search operators} reference"? X reference card?

I'm thinking about a help center instructions block, e.g.:

Opening the Keyboard shortcuts reference card

  1. ...

I erred away from 'card' in the original poll above, since that suffix was used for the 'mini-profile' naming I believe, and this seems like a larger overlay/popup. There's also only the one 'size', compared to the user profile? That said, I'm not aware if 'card' is used elsewhere for larger items currently, which might negate these concerns.
Yeah I like just "Search operators reference".
"Reference" doesn't seem great to me as a noun in the heading example above, which is why I tried adding "card". What do other folks think?

"Opening the keyboard shortcuts help" and "Opening the keyboard shortcuts reference overlay" seems fine to me.

(Nobody knows what an "overlay" is but the same is true for a "card", and it's not very card-like, in that those are usually small)
Mmm, I'm not a fan of "overlay". I agree that "card" is comparably mysterious, but "overlay" sounds unnecessarily technical to me.
"Keyboard shortcuts help" instead of one of the "... reference ??" variants is another option we can consider.
Anyway I think"Opening the keyboard keyboards reference|help|cheat sheet" all feel basically fine to me.
But I think "reference" describes very accurately what it is / how it can be used.

Would 'glossary' or 'index' work? I think both 'reference' and 'cheat sheet' would be okay too. I don't lean towards 'help' to keep it distinct from the help center documentation.

  • Keyboard shortcuts reference | Message formatting reference | Search filters reference
  • Keyboard shortcuts index | Message formatting index | Search filters index
  • Keyboard shortcuts glossary | Message formatting glossary | Search filters glossary
  • Keyboard shortcuts cheat sheet | Message formatting cheat sheet | Search filters cheat sheet
Ok, sounds like folks are pretty happy with "reference", so let's just go with that. I filed Add/improve documentation on the ? in-app reference #23758.
